image.altText: a red Tesla Model 3 sedan is charged at a Tesla dealership with the Tesla logo shown on the dealership building in the back

items.synopsis: Tesla's chief financial officer, Zachary Kirkhorn, leaves the electric car-maker, and US stocks finish higher after last week's losses ahead of inflation report.  Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Elon Musk successor steps down from Tesla, US stocks regain lost ground ahead of inflation report

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: James Hardie has provided an interesting result early in the corporate reporting season. The Australian building materials producer, which is heavily focused on the US market, reported falling first quarter sales (-5% to $US954 million) but an increased underlying profit. The company's adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (EBITDA) jumped 12% to $US279 million. The reason? A massive growth in profit margins. The company's adjusted EBITDA margin jumped from 24.9 to 29.2% over the past year. Both the company's US and Asia-Pacific fiber cement divisions posted record EBIT profit margins of 31.1% and 33.1% respectively. Those margins jumped 5.4 percentage points in the US and 7.5 percentage points in the Asia-Pacific region since its first quarter results a year ago. Slumping volumes saw the company's European building products division report a decrease in earnings, with rising costs keeping margins stagnant despite a steep rise in prices. Overall, the company ended up reporting a small (-3%) fall in its statutory net profit, which came in at $US157.8 million ($240 million).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: James Hardie grows profits on prices and margins as volumes fall

of 31.1% and 33.1% respectively.
Those margins jumped 5.4 percentage points in the US and 7.5 percentage points in the Asia-Pacific region since its first quarter results a year ago.
Slumping volumes saw the company's European building products division report a decrease in earnings, with rising costs keeping margins stagnant despite a steep rise in prices.
Overall, the company ended up reporting
a small (-3%) fall in its statutory net profit
, which came in at $US157.8 million ($240 million).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, welcome to the ABC's markets blog. I'm Sue Lannin. The big news this morning is the resignation of Tesla's chief financial officer Zachary Kirkhorn. Investors are worried because he's been seen as a possible successor to Tesla founder Elon Musk. Reuters reports that his departure has raised concerns about a succession plan at the world's most valuable carmaker. Tesla shares fell 3.5 per cent on the news. And US stocks had a good night after last week's sell-off, with the S & P 500 and the Nasdaq ending four days of losses. Warren Buffet's investment firm Berkshire Hathaway jumped to a record high after the company reported its quarterly operating profit topped $US10 billion ($15.2 billion) for the first time. Later this week, the US consumer price index will be released, a key piece of information for the US Federal Reserve and its next move on interest rates. US consumer prices saw their smallest annual increase in two years in June. Coming up today, we will get a reading of consumer confidence from Westpac and the Melbourne Institute and the National Australia Bank releases its latest business confidence survey. And building materials maker James Hardie reports its first quarter profit. Grab a coffee and let's go.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tesla finance chief steps down

children.content: Good morning, welcome to the ABC's markets blog. I'm Sue Lannin.
The big news this morning is the resignation of Tesla's chief financial officer Zachary Kirkhorn.
Investors are worried because he's been seen as a possible successor to Tesla founder Elon Musk.
Reuters reports that his departure has raised concerns about a succession plan at the world's most valuable carmaker.
Tesla shares fell 3.5 per cent on the news.
And US stocks had a good night after last week's sell-off, with the S
P 500 and the Nasdaq ending four days of losses.
Warren Buffet's investment firm Berkshire Hathaway
jumped to a record high after the company reported its quarterly operating profit topped $US10 billion ($15.2 billion) for the first time.
Later this week, the US consumer price index will be released, a key piece of information for the US Federal Reserve and its next move on interest rates.
US consumer prices saw their smallest annual increase in two years in June.
Coming up today, we will get a reading of consumer confidence from Westpac and the Melbourne Institute and the National Australia Bank releases its latest business confidence survey.
And building materials maker James Hardie reports its first quarter profit.
Grab a coffee and let's go.

title.children: Judge dismisses Donald Trump's defamation claim against E. Jean Carroll — The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Brad Ryan in Washington DC There’s been a small development in Donald Trump's court case here in Washington DC. If you were following the news last week, you'd know Trump was indicted on conspiracy charges related to efforts to overturn the 2020 election result. After last week's court appearance, Trump posted on his Truth Social platform: "IF YOU GO AFTER ME, I'M COMING AFTER YOU!" That threatening post prompted prosecutors to respond with a late-night court application to have the former president prevented from going too far with his social posts. In particular, prosecutors raised concerns Trump could publicly reveal confidential material that they will need to give his legal team as part of the court process. They asked the court to issue a "protective order" that would restrict any sharing of that material to a select group of people with a direct stake in the case. A short time ago, Trump's legal team formally responded to the prosecution's request, asking the court to narrow the proposed order "to shield only genuinely sensitive materials from public view". It says the prosecutors' request represents an attempt by the government to limit Trump's First Amendment free speech rights. "Worse, it does this against this administration's primary political opponent, during an election season in which the administration, prominent party members, and media allies have campaigned on the indictment," the response lodged with the court says. The court is yet to decide on the application.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prosecutors are attempting to limit Trump's posting about his indictment

children.content: By Brad Ryan in Washington DC
There’s been a small development in Donald Trump's court case here in Washington DC.
If you were following the news last week, you'd know Trump was indicted on conspiracy charges related to efforts to overturn the 2020 election result.
After last week's court appearance, Trump posted on his Truth Social platform: "IF YOU GO AFTER ME, I'M COMING AFTER YOU!"
That threatening post prompted prosecutors to respond with a late-night court application
to have the former president prevented from going too far with his social posts.

props.alt: Donald Trump speaking at a lecturn in a suit and tie

children.content: (AP: Artie Walker Jr.)
In particular,
prosecutors raised concerns Trump could publicly reveal confidential material
that they will need to give his legal team as part of the court process.
They asked the court to issue a "protective order" that would restrict any sharing of that material to a select group of people with a direct stake in the case.
A short time ago, Trump's legal team formally responded to the prosecution's request, asking the court to
narrow the proposed order
"to shield only genuinely sensitive materials from public view".
It says the prosecutors' request represents an attempt by the government to limit Trump's First Amendment free speech rights.

"Worse, it does this against this administration's primary political opponent, during an election season in which the administration, prominent party members, and media allies have campaigned on the indictment," the response lodged with the court says.
The court is yet to decide on the application.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A federal judge in the US has tossed out former president Donald Trump's countersuit against writer E. Jean Carroll, who won a $US5 million ($7.6 million) sex abuse lawsuit against him in May. The judge ruled that Trump can't claim Carroll defamed him by continuing to say she was not only sexually abused but raped. Trump attorney Alina Habba says Trump's lawyers will appeal "the flawed decision" to dismiss his counterclaim. Carroll is also pursuing her own defamation suit against Trump. Her lawyer, Robbie Kaplan, says Carroll is pleased with the ruling and looking ahead to a trial scheduled in January in her defamation suit, which concerns a series of remarks that Trump has made in denying her sexual assault allegation. Carroll accuses Trump of trapping her in a luxury department store dressing room in 1996, where the alleged incident occurred. Trump denies any of it happened, and even that they ran into each other at the store. He has accused her of inventing "a fraudulent and false story" to sell a memoir.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Judge dismisses Donald Trump's defamation suit against E. Jean Carroll, who he was found to have sexually abused

props.alt: Donald Trump in a suit and tie holding an umbrella in the rain next to a car

children.content: (AP: Alex Brandon)
A federal judge in the US has tossed out former president Donald Trump's countersuit against writer E. Jean Carroll, who won a $US5 million ($7.6 million) sex abuse lawsuit against him in May.
The judge ruled that Trump can't claim Carroll defamed him by continuing to say she was not only sexually abused but raped.
Trump attorney Alina Habba says Trump's lawyers will appeal "the flawed decision" to dismiss his counterclaim.
Carroll is also pursuing her own defamation suit against Trump.

Her lawyer, Robbie Kaplan, says Carroll is pleased with the ruling and looking ahead to a trial scheduled in January in her defamation suit, which concerns a series of remarks that Trump has made in denying her sexual assault allegation.
Carroll accuses Trump of trapping her in a luxury department store dressing room in 1996
, where the alleged incident occurred.
Trump denies any of it happened, and even that they ran into each other at the store. He has accused her of inventing "a fraudulent and false story" to sell a memoir.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An investigation into the weekend's fatal house fire on Brisbane's bayside is trying to establish whether there were working smoke alarms at the property. Wayne Godinet, 34, and his five young sons died in the early morning blaze on Russell Island on Sunday. The boys' mother, Samantha Stephenson, and another woman survived the fire. Queensland Fire and Emergency Services Commissioner Greg Leach says by law, the home should have been fitted with at least one hard-wired smoke alarm. "Hopefully we can determine that either by finding remains of a smoke alarm site, although as I said it's been a very hot fire or we might be able to track through council records whether it was compliant at the time it was moved there," he said. The cause of the fire is being investigated, with police saying yesterday they were keeping an open mind about whether or not it was suspicious.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Investigators contiue to comb scene of Russell Island fire tragedy

children.content: An investigation into the weekend's fatal house fire on Brisbane's bayside is trying to establish whether there were working smoke alarms at the property.
Wayne Godinet, 34, and his five young sons died in the early morning blaze on Russell Island on Sunday.
The boys' mother, Samantha Stephenson, and another woman survived the fire.
Queensland Fire and Emergency Services Commissioner Greg Leach says by law, the home should have been fitted with at least one hard-wired smoke alarm.

"Hopefully we can determine that either by finding remains of a smoke alarm site, although as I said it's been a very hot fire or we might be able to track through council records whether it was compliant at the time it was moved there," he said.
The cause of the fire is being investigated, with police saying yesterday they were keeping an open mind about whether or not it was suspicious.
